questions.text: A new biological therapy, Anakinra has been developed for treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis. What is the mechanism of action of anakinra?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IL-1 antagonist

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. TNF antagonist: This option is incorrect. TNF antagonists are a class of biologics that include drugs such as infliximab , etanercept , and adalimumab . They work by inhibiting the action of tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), not IL-1.

  • • TNF antagonists
  • • class of biologics
  • • drugs such as infliximab
  • • etanercept
  • • adalimumab
  • • Option C. IL-2 antagonist: This option is incorrect. IL-2 antagonists , such as basiliximab and daclizumab , are used primarily to prevent rejection in organ transplantation by inhibiting the action of interleukin-2 (IL-2), which is different from the mechanism of action of anakinra.
  • • Option C. IL-2 antagonist:
  • • IL-2 antagonists
  • • basiliximab and daclizumab
  • • prevent rejection
  • • organ transplantation
  • • inhibiting the action of interleukin-2
  • • Option D. IL-6 antagonist: This option is incorrect. IL-6 antagonists , such as tocilizumab and sarilumab , are used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis by inhibiting the action of interleukin-6 (IL-6), a different pathway from that targeted by anakinra.
  • • Option D. IL-6 antagonist:
  • • IL-6 antagonists
  • • tocilizumab and sarilumab
  • • treatment of rheumatoid arthritis
  • • inhibiting the action of interleukin-6

Recognizing anakinra as an IL-1 antagonist is crucial for understanding its role in managing inflammation and joint damage in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, highlighting the importance of targeted biological therapies in modulating specific pathways involved in the disease process.

  • • inferior vena cava
  • • bypassing the liver
  • • Option D. Premature closure of ductus venosus: Like the patent ductus venosus , premature closure of this vessel is not a recognized outcome of indomethacin use in pregnancy . The ductus venosus naturally closes after birth as part of the normal transition from fetal to neonatal circulation.
